tips.tip: Replace your Aerobika annually according to manufacturer guidelines, even if it appears to be working. The instructions state replacement after one year or if damaged. If your device fails to flutter or requires using it upside down to work, contact Monaghan Medical customer service for a replacement - they provide good customer support for defective units.
tips.notes: Manufacturer PDF page 6 specifies 1-year replacement. Device can work in any position but shouldn't require it.

tips.tip: Start slowly with Aerobika use if you're new to airway clearance. Begin with 10 breaths 4 times a day rather than 20-minute sessions. Some patients experience lightheadedness and faintness from prolonged use initially. Work up gradually to the recommended 10-20 minutes twice daily as your body adapts. Listen to your respiratory therapist's guidance and your own body.
tips.notes: Patient experienced severe lightheadedness from 30 breaths, spent afternoon in bed. Respiratory therapist recommended shorter, more frequent sessions.

tips.tip: Continue airway clearance twice daily even when you're not producing sputum. The gold standard is twice-daily treatment 'in sickness and in health' - it's both preventative and curative. Antibiotics temporarily dry out sputum, so lack of production doesn't mean you should reduce clearance. Multiple patients and physicians confirm ongoing twice-daily clearance maintains lung health.
tips.notes: Antibiotics reduce sputum temporarily but ACT must continue. Dr. Daley endorsed flexible timing as long as twice daily maintained.

tips.tip: For the vest + nebulizer + Aerobika timing debate: Dr. Pamela McShane (National Jewish Health) recommends nebulizing first, then using vest and Aerobika separately - not simultaneously. The nebulizer opens airways while the vest compresses them, working against each other. However, many physicians approve simultaneous use because the time commitment (50-60 min sequential vs 30 min simultaneous) affects compliance. Discuss with your doctor which approach fits your lifestyle.
tips.notes: Dr. McShane webinar at ~1hr 5min mark addresses this. Time burden vs optimal technique trade-off.

tips.tip: Wash Aerobika parts in Dawn dish soap and rinse after each use, then sterilize daily using one of these methods: (1) Baby bottle sterilizer with sterilize + dry cycle, (2) Boil for 10 minutes in water, (3) Microwave steam bags (Medela brand) for 3 minutes, or (4) Dishwasher sanitize cycle at 140°F in a fine mesh bag. Store sterilized parts in sealed plastic bags - they remain sterile for years as long as they don't contact water or dust.
tips.notes: Dr. Falkinham confirmed sterilized items stay sterile indefinitely in sealed bags. Multiple validated sterilization methods available.

tips.tip: When boiling Aerobika in hard water that leaves white mineral deposits, you can add 2 tablespoons of distilled white vinegar to the water to prevent buildup. The device won't be damaged and vinegar won't remain on parts after sterilization. Alternatively, use LifeStraw-filtered water, bottled spring water, or reuse distilled water for multiple boiling sessions (keep covered, top off as needed, replace weekly).
tips.notes: Multiple patients confirm vinegar + boiling safe. Distilled water reuse cuts costs. Spring water still has minerals.

tips.tip: If albuterol or levalbuterol makes you jittery when nebulizing with Aerobika, try these alternatives: (1) Switch from albuterol to levalbuterol (less jittery for most), (2) Use 2 puffs of levalbuterol inhaler instead of nebulized form, (3) Try Atrovent (ipratropium) instead, or (4) Skip the bronchodilator entirely if your PFT shows it doesn't improve your lung function. Many patients use 3% saline alone successfully.
tips.notes: PFT testing showed some patients get no benefit from albuterol. Levalbuterol causes less tachycardia. Mamie Balestra dropped albuterol after PFT confirmation.

tips.tip: Time your twice-daily airway clearance sessions on an empty stomach for best results. Most patients do first session upon waking (before breakfast), then struggle with timing the second. Common strategies: (1) Early afternoon 12pm-4pm before dinner, (2) Before bed around 10pm (3+ hours post-dinner), or (3) Right after work around 5pm. Six hours minimum between sessions is ideal. Choose timing you can maintain consistently.
tips.notes: Dr. Daley approved flexible timing as long as compliance maintained. Morning clearance most productive for many.

tips.tip: Buy replacement Aerobika devices from reputable medical supply companies like SaveRite Medical ($50-60 range) rather than eBay or Mercari. Devices on secondary marketplaces may be taken from hospital inventory or used. Insurance rarely covers replacement within the 1-year window, so budget $50-60 annually for a new device from legitimate suppliers.
tips.notes: Linda Esposito recommends SaveRite Medical. Hospital devices may be diverted to resale sites. UDI stamps don't guarantee authenticity.

tips.tip: The Aerobika is effective in any position (upright, tilted, or even upside down), so you can use it with postural drainage positions if desired. However, if your device only works upside down when it's less than 6 months old, this indicates a defect - contact the manufacturer for replacement under warranty.
tips.notes: Linda Esposito confirmed position doesn't affect efficacy. Early malfunction indicates defect.

tips.tip: Soaking Aerobika parts in vinegar solution (3 cups water + 3 cups vinegar for 1 hour) monthly helps maintain the flutter mechanism and can fix devices that have stopped fluttering properly. Some patients also blow hard through the exhale end to clear any buildup. This is maintenance, not sterilization - still boil or steam sterilize after vinegar soak.
tips.notes: Debra Walker's monthly vinegar maintenance routine. Helps extend device function.

tips.tip: Exercise is a powerful complement to Aerobika use for airway clearance. Hiking hills, biking, swimming, or even fast walking loosens mucus effectively. Many patients find aerobic exercise produces more sputum than Aerobika alone. Combine both approaches - exercise helps shake things loose, then use Aerobika and postural drainage to complete the clearance.
tips.notes: Multiple patients report exercise + ACT more effective than ACT alone. Swimming particularly effective.

key_insights: Aerobika/OPEP devices are prescribed for twice-daily use indefinitely - it's a lifetime commitment for bronchiectasis and NTM patients, not just during active infection.

The timing controversy (simultaneous vs sequential use with vest/nebulizer) reflects real trade-offs between optimal technique and patient compliance - Dr. McShane recommends sequential, but many doctors approve simultaneous use to reduce time burden from 50-60 minutes to 30 minutes.
Annual replacement is required even though devices may seem to work fine - the internal mechanisms degrade over time, and manufacturer guidelines specify 1-year maximum use.
Albuterol jitteriness affects many patients but has multiple alternatives (levalbuterol, Atrovent, inhaler instead of nebulizer, or skipping bronchodilator entirely if PFT shows no benefit).
Sterilization methods are flexible - baby bottle sterilizers, boiling, microwave steam bags, and dishwasher sanitize cycles all work, allowing patients to choose what fits their lifestyle.
The 'not producing sputum' phenomenon doesn't mean airway clearance is unnecessary - antibiotics dry secretions temporarily, and preventative clearance is as important as clearing active mucus.
Exercise significantly enhances Aerobika effectiveness - the combination of aerobic activity + ACT produces better clearance than ACT alone for many patients.
Hard water mineral buildup is a common frustration but solvable with vinegar additions or distilled water reuse strategies that reduce costs.
